rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The seat of government question (1839-1859).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: To begin in the year 1839, the chapter wou1d open with the promise of "Union", enter immediately upon a disillusioning period of discord and hasten to a final reconciliatian .. which in itself would preface the approaoh of Confederation. The narration in fu11 would present (almost) a comp1ete suryey of Canadian politics from the days before the Union to those preceding the Dominion. In its course would figure every character known to the public at that time. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canada -- History -- 1841-1867.
Ottawa (Ont.) -- History.
History.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The nature of the resins of jack pine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The question of the composition and properties of the resinous secretions of Jack Pine (Pinus Banksiana) has formed a subject of peculiar interest during the past few years. Comparatively little is known of the chemical nature of the mixture of natural substances, generally referred to broadly as "resina", which is secreted in the inner cells of such coniferous woods. On the other hand, the oleoresins, particularly those forming the raw material of the Naval Stores industry, have been subject to considerable investigation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Fifty years of industrial transition in the British navy : from sail to steam and from wood to iron (1820-1870).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The coming of the age of coal and iron and the advent of machinery made themselves felt in the British navy much later than in industrial processes and in industrial organisationon land. The steam-engine and the iron-clad were certainly not predominant in the Royal Navy until almost forty years after the attainment of supremacy by the new industrial processes in the cotton textile industry. It mas after the year i860 that the era of rapid and continual evolution in naval construction really began. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Great Britain. Royal Navy -- History.
History.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le travail dans l’oeuvre de Pierre Hamp.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: La question du travail bien qu'elle n'ait pas été entièrement négligée en l1ttérature, n'a cependant rarement reçu autant d'attention que ne lui accorde de nos jours M. Pierre Hamp, dont toute l'oeuvre est fondée sur une êtùde approfondie de cette question. Des diffêrentes manières d'envisager le travail, M. Hamp a choisi celle qui nous le montre comme une force qui empèche l'ouvrier de trouver dans les conditions actuelles du travai1 le contentement et la satisfaction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effects of solutions of dextrose and various electrolytes,introvenously administered, on the rate of secretion and composition of the urine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: When a quantity of isotonic dextrose solution equivalent to about one fourth the blood volume is injected intravenously into an unanesthetized dog, diuresis ensues and within from 1.5 to 2.5 hours the volume of urine secreted approximates that of the injected solution. On the other hand, if an isotonic sodium chloride solution is injected instead of the dextrose solution urine secretion is much less affected. A possible explanation for this difference may be stated as follows: When an isotonic dextrose solution is injectedthere is probably no esse'ltial disturbance in the equilibrium of those substances in the body which affect the water balance of the organism. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The inorganic constituents of eggyolk.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The earliest available chernical analyses of the constituents of eggs were performed by Foleck and Weber in 1849. They determined the inorganic constituents of both yolk and white, and gave a rough estimate of the nitrogen content. Konig reported an analysis of eggs by Bostock as early as 1855. Langworthy, working for the United States Department of Agriculture, made more extensive analyses of all the constituents. He determined these in whole eggs, with and without shell, and on the white and yolk separately. He then found the differences in moisture content of raw and boiled material. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: La crise de l'adolescence, telle qu'elle apparaitdans les romans français parus depuis la guerre de 1914-1918.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: On aurait pu craindre que la période d'après guerre ne vît diminuer la production littéraire et en particulier celle des romans. Il n'en est rien. Sans doute, nombre d'auteurs ou futurs auteurs ont disparu dans la tourmente, mais ceux qui restent semblent être atteints, par compensation, d'une fécondité inépuisable, voire même inquiétante, car la qualiténe semble pas aller toujours de pair aveo la quantité. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Surface energy relationships.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A great deal of the scientific interest in recent years has centered in the relationships between various physical properties and the chemical constitution of organic compounds. Properties of liquids, particularly, have been examined, and among these surface energy and its related properties have been of considerable interest. In this thesis will bedescribed the determination of a number of surface energy relationships for a series of isomeric organic liquids. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: On the double striations in hydrogen.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It has been known for many years that when an electric current passes through gases at pressures of the order of 1 mm. of mercury the continuous positive column breaks up into discontinuous luminous 41805, called striations. Suoh 8triat1one were first observed by M. Abrla in 1843 and independently reobserved by Sir William Grove in 1862(1). The most interesting classical work is that of De la Rue and Miller(2). These authors experimented with tubes of various sizes and shapes obtaining many remarkable and interesting phenomena. Among the observations which they record is the fact that under certain oonditions of pressure and current density the striations in hydrogen were grouped in pairs and indeed in Bome of their photographs 1ndications of triplets can be detected, though no mention of this latter fact is made by the authors. In all their tubes, ring and pointed wire electrodes were used and as a source of potential a battery of silver chlor1de ce1ls. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The pauperization of the Roman populace during the later Republican period : with special reference to Frumentarian laws and distributions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The history of Rome tells us of two great movements, namely. the expansion of the city by the River Tiber into an Empire embracing the civilized world of the day; and the political and constitutional development by which the institutions of a small farming community were adapted to the government, first of Italy, then of the Roman Empire. Interwoven with these two great movements in the fabric of Roman history, like coloured threads which, scarcely discernible at first, seem gradually to increase in number until the whole material is dominated by them, may be traced the rise and growth of the Roman Populace and its ever-increasing pauperism. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Rome -- Economic conditions.
Rome -- Social conditions.
Latin.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The action of histamine on the secretory and motor phenomena in the digestive tract.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Of the different substances which can be obtained from extracts of various animal organs, histamine deserves special consideration. It has the greatest physiological activity of any of the known amines, producing marked toxic symptoms when given to an animal, and yet it is derived readily from the harmless amino acid histidine, present in nearly all proteins. There are few pharmacological substances which, when injected in small doses, produce such a general reaction as 'this amine. It has a pronounced effect on the circulatory and respiratory systems. All the digestive glands are stimulated following its administration. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Gastrointestinal system -- Motility.
Digestive organs -- Secretions.
Physiology.
Histamine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation between religion and ethics.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Early ages seem to have given little thought to the problem of the relation between religion and ethics. This may be explained by the fact that reflective and critical thought is very rare in the early history of the human race. Whatever the oauses may bet the facts are: primitive peoples knew little of religion as such, but the little that they had, permeated the whole of life and no distination was made between the sacred and the seoular. This does not mean that ethics and religion were inseparably united at this stage - thatquestion will be discussed later. All that we wish to make clear here, is that the human race in its earliest history took its standard of morals and its religion as a matter of course and gave no thought to the connection between them. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The structure and function of the lateral line and development of the vertebral column in aquatic amphibia.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The skin and especially the large skin glands of amphibia have been the subjects of much study and discussion since Ascherson's investigations on the skin-glands of the frog in 1840. But in spite of this extensive work, one fails to find very much in the field of the structure of the lateral line organ of aquatic amphibia. It is mentioned often; its distribution is also given, but only a few authors have dealt with its actual structure. Very closely connected with the structure of the organs of the lateral line is its function. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Zoology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development and influence of Newman’s ecclesiastical views.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: No student of the life and literature of England in the nineteenth century can afford to neglect a consideration of the religious upheavals which took place in that disturbed age. While in economics, politics and science entirely new theories were being worked out and presented to the unsettled minds of the public, in art, literature and religion many men were turning back to seek their models in centuries gone by. There is thus a certain connection between the Pre-Raphaelites, the Romanticists and the Tractarians. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Newman, John Henry, 1801-1890.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in cholesterosis.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cholesterol is one of the most mysterious substances found in the living organism. Although universally present in the cells of the body its purpose is still unknown; discoveredby Conradi in 1775 its chemical structure remains indefinite and its analyysis difficult; insoluble in water, still it manages to permeate the whole body and its amount, in bloodand bile, waxes and wanes like the tide with every meal, and with almost every pathological vicissitude undergone by the body. Even the very crystal of cholesterol, for some unknownreason, has a notch in one of its angles. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The doctrine of the will as consent.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A word of explanation may be appropriate regarding the title chosen for this thesis. Its selection was made prior to the investigations which are embodied in the text, and was taken chiefly because it expressed a point of view regarding human motivation which seemed to hold possibilities of fruitful exploration. Much has been written about the will, in theology and moral philosophy, so that it seemed idle to add more words on a subject about which past controversy has chiefly succeeded in hanging a thick fog, unless some new way of piercing the gloom lay open. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Inter-imperial trade in cotton textiles, 1914-1928.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In making the following study an attempt has been made to base all conclusions on facts alone, and these facts have been secured from official and authoritative sources which should be reliable. In some cases it has not been possible to obtain pre-war statistics, and in other cases to obtain them up to 1928. For these and other shortcomings an apology is made, and the difficulty of getting information about the many distant countries covered in the study pleaded in extenuation. When it has been possible to obtain information more recent than 1928 it has been used. Generous help was received from many persons and organizations. The Canadian Trade Commissioners in India, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa; the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, Ottawa; the Department of Customs and the Department of Industries and Commerce of New Zealand; and finally, the Conmonwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics, Allstralia, sent a great deal of very useful information. The Foreign Tariffs Division of the Department of Trade and Commerce, Ottawa; courteously allowed a study of its tariff files. The British Trade Commissioner, the Canadian Textile Journal, the Dominion Textile Company, the Sun Life Assurance Company and Messrs. Cockf1eld, Brown and Company, all of Montreal, generously lent vaiuable books and other publications. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science.
Cotton trade.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Unemployment in the men’s clothing industry of Montreal.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The spectacle of men who are able and willing to work in order to provide for themselves the necessities of life, and who are unable to find employment, is not an edifying one. When these unemployed number hundreds of thousands, and are spread throughout the world, they constitute a threat to society; but chronic unemployment of a seasonal nature which persists during good times and bad is just as formidable an indictment on industry. Everyone knows the paradox of cyclical unemployment. When granaries are overflowing and other commodities are plenteous there are people who are hungry and ill-clothed; when the well-being of the farmer seems to depend on a poor harvest, the paradox is baffling. Solutions are rendered difficult by the elusiveness of the problem and disagreement among authorities as to underlying causes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Unemployment -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal.
Economics & Political Science.
Men’s clothing industry -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in photochemistry.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A study of certain aspects of the photosynthesis of hydrogen chloride has been made. In this study particular attention has been given to the following points: the temperature coefficients of the light absorption and of the quantum yield, for different wave-lengths; the so-called photochemical threshold; the variation of quantum yield with light intensity; and the effect of the walls on the chain character ot the reaction. Two general methods were employed in attacking the problem. The first was a modified Bunsen-RoscoeTechnique. Filtered monochromatic light from a mercury arc was passed into a reaction cell containing besides hydrogen and chlorine at atmospheric pressure a small volume of water to absorb the hyrdogen chloride formed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The comparison of gaseous densities by the method of balancing columns, with applications.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: If two gases of different densities are placed respectively in two vertical columns arranged as in fig. 1 (Drovision being made that the pressure is the same at the tops of the two columns), then the difference in density of the gases will produce a difference in the hydrostatic pressure at the bases of the columns. Or, conversely, we can say that the reading of a suitable pressure gauge connected between the bases of two suah columns is a measure of the difference in density between the gases which they contain. This is theprinciple involved in the "balanced columns" method of comparing the densities of gases or gaseous mixtures. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Theory and application of photo-elasticity.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Theory of e1asticity treats of the analysis of stresses set up in a body, subjected to external forces. It leads us to differential equations which have :Jeen solved only in a few simple cases. For calculating stresses set up in structures the Theory of Strength of Materials has been developed from pure Elasticity, by making certain assumptions and approximations. It leads us to solutions, which, although not exact, are accurate enough for engineering purposes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in organic peracids.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work to be described in the following pages is an outgrowth of investigations into the oxidation of organic compounds, which have been carried on in this laboratory for the past ten years. Its chief feature may be said to be the conductivity of organic peracids. In order, however, to provide the correct setting of this work it is necessary to review at somelength all those previous studies which have a direct bearing on the subject. No apology is offered for the length of the review which follows, as it is essential that thehistorical sequence be accurately presented.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L’eau dans l’oeuvre de Lamartine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: On a trop ignore l'importance de l'eau dans l'oeuvre de Lamartine. C'est à peine, en y pensant, si l'on peut citer un autre poème que le Lac ou' elle est présente. Pour ceux qui 1' ont etudié de près cette ignorance semble incroyable. Mais la verve poétique, le style du poète, n'ont ils pas l'harmonie et la fluidité mêmes de l'eau? Il y a une concordance parfaite entre cet element, pur et limpide et les vers du poète. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Lamartine, Alphonse de, 1790-1869 -- Criticism and interpretation.
French.
Water in literature.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Triangular preferential trade.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Imperial Preference in matters of trade is by no means an invention of the 1ater nineteenth century. There is this difference, however, between the preferential system of our time and that which preceded it --- today mutual concessions are granted by autonomous units of the British Commonwealth of Nations, whereas under the Old Oolonial System the fiscal policy for the whole Empire was determined by the Mother Country, England. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Role of hyaluronic acid in human placenta-derived mesenchymal stem cells in myocardial regeneration
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Introduction: Ischemic heart disease continues to be one of the leading causes of death worldwide. Myocardial damage resulting from ischemia is often associated with an irreversible loss of functional cardiomyocytes, which ultimately leads to heart failure.Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are multipotent cells with the ability to differentiate into cardiomyocytes and endothelial cells, therefore providing a potential therapy for ischemic cardiomyopathy. Hyaluronic acid (HA), a non-sulfated glycosaminoglycan, is a major component of the extra-cellular matrix (ECM) and can also act as a ligand to cell surface receptors to stimulate cellular activities; most notably through its major receptor CD44. CD44 is a trans-membrane glycoprotein receptor that can bind to HA, and through this interaction regulates cellular activities such as proliferation, migration, apoptosis and angiogenesis by triggering downstream signaling cascades. Our objectives are to evaluate the effects hyaluronic acid has on the biology of human placenta-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hpMSCs) in regulating cellular proliferation, migration, apoptosis and determining the involvement of CD44 receptors in these interactions.Methods: Cellular proliferation was assessed using the MTT proliferation assay after exposing hpMSCs to different concentrations of HA for 48 hours. The involvement of CD44 receptors in this process was tested by adding a group treated with an anti-CD44 receptors monoclonol antibody (anti-CD44 mAb) before exposure to HA. Cellular migration was assessed using the trans-well migration assay and by counting the number of cells that migrated from the upper compartment to the lower compartment after 18 hours. Three groups were tested: the first being the control group with non-coated membranes, followed by two other groups, which were seeded on the HA-coated membranes with or without anti-CD44 mAb treatment. Annexin V and Propidium Iodide were used to measure cellular apoptosis after exposing the cells to different conditions including HA and the cytotoxic agent Cisplatin. The stained cells were sorted using a Fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) machine.Results: Contrary to cells exposed to high molecular weight HA, the growth and proliferation of hpMSCs exposed to low molecular weight HA increased in a dose dependent manner from 10-200 μg/ml. HA showed a cytoprotective role by increasing the live cell population in cells treated with Cisplatin from 74.5% to 85.9%. HA-coated membranes significantly increased hpMSCs migration, whereas in hpMSCs with blocked CD44 receptors, migration declined significantly through HA-coated membranes.Conclusions: Thus far, the use of MSCs in myocardial regeneration has been limited due to the low survivability and low engraftment rate of stem cells. To address these limitations, further experimentation in the use of scaffolds is required to enhance the efficiency of cellular therapy in myocardial regeneration. Studying the effect of HA on hpMSCs can help us better understand and determine the most effective method to implement hydrogel based scaffolds in myocardial regeneration. As our data suggests, HA affords beneficial outcomes in regards to the proliferation, migration and cytoprotection of hpMSCs. This indicates that HA based hydrogels not only act as a scaffold to hold these cells, but also provide a stimulating niche at the site of injury, which increases the effectiveness of stem cell therapy.

Introduction: La cardiopathie ischémique est toujours l'une des principales causes de décès dans le monde entier. Les dommages résultant d'une ischémie du myocarde est souvent associée à une perte irréversible de cardiomyocytes fonctionnels, ce qui conduit finalement à une insuffisance cardiaque.Les cellules souches mésenchymateuses sont des cellules pluripotentes qui ont la capacité de se différencier en cardiomyocytes et des cellules endothéliales, offrant ainsi une thérapie potentielle pour la cardiomyopathie ischémique. L'acide hyaluronique (HA), est une composante majeure de la matrice extracellulaire et peut également agir comme un ligand à des récepteurs de surface cellulaire pour stimuler les activités cellulaires notamment par son récepteur CD44 majeur. Le CD44 est un récepteur qui peut se lier au HA et c’est cette interaction qui régule les activités. Nos objectifs sont d'évaluer l'effet de l'acide hyaluronique sur les cellules souches mésenchymateuses placentaires humaines dérivées (hpCSM) la biologie dans la régulation de la prolifération cellulaire, la migration, l'apoptose et la détermination de l'implication des récepteurs CD44 dans ces interactions.Méthodes: La prolifération cellulaire a été évaluée en utilisant le test MTT de prolifération après exposition au hpCSMs à différentes concentrations de HA pour 48 heures tandis que la participation des récepteurs CD44 dans le processus a été testé par l'ajout d'un groupe traité avec un récepteurs anti-CD44 monoclonol anticorps (anti-CD44 mAb) avant l'exposition au HA. La migration cellulaire a été évaluée en utilisant l'essai de migration transwell et en comptant le nombre de cellules ayant migré à partir du compartiment supérieur au compartiment inférieur après 18 heures, trois groupes ont été testés, soit le groupe de contrôle avec des membranes non revêtues et les deux autres groupes étaient ensemencées sur les membranes revêtues de HA avec ou sans anti-CD44 mAb traitement. L'annexine V et l'iodure de propidium ont été utilisés pour la mesure de l'apoptose des cellules après l'exposition des celles-ci à des conditions, y compris l'agent HA et cytotoxique du cisplatine. Les cellules colorées ont été triées en utilisant le machine de tri cellulaire fluorcsente (FACS).Résultats: Après exposition à bas poids moléculaire HA, et contrairement aux cellules exposées au HA de masse moléculaire élevée, la croissance et la prolifération des cellules souches mésenchymateuses ont été augmenté d'une manière dépendante de la dose de 10 à 200 μg / ml. Le HA a montré un rôle cytoprotecteur en augmentant la population de cellules vivantes dans les cellules traitées avec le cisplatine de 74,5% à 85,9%. Les membranes revêtues de HA ont augmenté de manière significative la migration des hpCSMs, alors que dans les hpCSMs avec récepteurs CD44 bloqués, les migrations ont diminué de façon significative à travers les membranes revêtues de HA.Conclusions: L'utilisation des cellules souches mésenchymateuses dans la régénération du myocarde a été jusqu'à présent limitée en raison de la faible capacité de survie et du faible taux de cellules souches de la prise de greffe. Pour remédier à ces limitations, une expérimentation plus poussée de l'utilisation d'échafaudages est nécessaire pour augmenter l'efficacité de la thérapie cellulaire dans la régénération du myocarde. Étudier l'effet du HA sur le CSMs peut nous aider à mieux comprendre et déterminer la méthode la plus efficace pour utiliser les échafaudages à base d'hydrogel dans la régénération du myocarde. Comme nos données le suggère, HA contribue un rôle important dans la prolifération, la migration et la cytoprotection des cellules souches mésenchymateuses, indiquant que les hydrogels basés HA agissent non seulement comme un échafaudage pour maintenir ces cellules, mais fournissent aussi une niche stimulante au site de la lésion qui augmente l'efficacité de thérapie par cellules souches.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Surgery
